text: Composite image of 13 Eta Aquariid meteors from the NASA Camera in Mayhill, New Mexico the morning of May 6, 2013 http://t.co/2YaHAFz20G
Lyrids hit our atmosphere at speeds of ~105,000 mph and burn up around an altitude of 53 miles. The lowest last night was 44 miles.
NASA cameras detected 20 Lyrid fireballs last night! Here is a orbit plot (purple line belongs to Comet Thatcher) http://t.co/UDWaAGohzd
Traveling at 107,000 mph, this Lyrid burned up 60 miles above McMinnville, TN. http://t.co/YHiAQbM8UK
A bright Lyrid meteor burns up 55 miles above Edgefield, SC. Peak activity should be just before dawn tomorrow. http://t.co/zL4c7XIniV
Sign of the times: A fireball ablates 34 miles above NMSU's campus. This is normal for this month - keep an eye out! http://t.co/SB5hoZLykn
@marekhladik Hope you saw some Geminids!
@Marvellisaywahh Sure. You need a good math & science background. School = calculus & high level math, & many many physics & astro classes.

text: melindamanion90: So sorry to hear about your poor weather! Hopefully tomorrow night! ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Feel free to keep asking us questions via twitter on the Geminid meteor shower! And don't forget to go outside and look for yourself!
@plocknelswain: Yes! Many Geminids have been seen in the live stream. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
The Geminids are named for the constellation Gemini, where the radiant is located. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Geminids travel about 60 times faster than the Concorde jet. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
marcusspencer560: You don't have to target any particular constellations. Just look up! ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
barneykoerner: The camera is pointed towards north, 61 degrees elevation. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
wvlana: Yes, best viewing time is between 2 and 5 am local time. When radiant is highest. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
mlj_8096: We see many meteors with this camera - 77 Geminids last night alone! ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
http://t.co/dGzAerQO answering lots of questions on Geminids on our live chat!
@mitchelliii Fantastic! #meteorwatch
deletrickdickerson: "Peak time" is the time the shower will produce max # of meteors per hr ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
susankropp12: Cam is pointing north at an elev of 61 deg ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
@Hillarya_miller An outburst is above-normal rates. A meteor storm is when there are 1,000+ meteors an hour. The Leonids have stormed a lot.
@Hillarya_miller Radar can see meteors 24 hours a day, not hampered by daylight or poor weather, thus we use radar data a lot.
@MaryDaGinger85 Very possible! The biggest meteors have reports of sonic booms being heard. Very fun that you got to see that!
@Hillarya_miller Members of our group have degrees in astrophysics, aerospace engineering, astronomy, and physics. A nice variety!
@Hillarya_miller With multi-station observations of meteors we can determine the meteor trajectory and orbit.
@Hillarya_miller Thank you so much for your questions. Myself, Danielle, and Bill (members of the MEO) enjoy this.
@Hillarya_miller GEM predictions are usually pretty good. But there's always room for surprises. :-)
@Hillarya_miller ...important to model, especially if they are known to outburst.
@Hillarya_miller Geminids are very predictable. There are other meteor showers (Draconids, for example) that are not. They are more...
jessicaruggiero37: Congrats! ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Dakota Ensminger: The camera is located at NASA Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville AL ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Cam is b&w, low-light level Watec CCD video camera with 22x16 deg field of view ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Brianna Scarlet Terry: Max rate approx 100/hr at peak ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
johnsavage35110: Minnesota can see GEMs if clear weather, dark skies ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Jade Cadaver: Geometry isn't good for observing GEMs on the Moon this year. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Jade Cadaver: In space: meteoroids. Look like bits of rock/ice. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
@Hillarya_miller Speed,heights,etc at which they ablate.We also take data to compare our models that predict activity, with actual activity.
isabel9x: NJ can see it though light pollution will reduce # of GEMs seen ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
javiermontes16: Bright lights in Chicago will reduce the number of GEMs seen ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Jade Cadaver: From earth, meteoroids impacting the moon look like a flash of light ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
ubstudxer: The music is Third Rock Radio ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
wizardmike: Actually, don't look toward Gemini, look up! Get the most sky coverage. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
jonankers: Great! Glad to hear that. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
@Hillarya_miller Cool! You are seeing them burn up by 45 miles up! #meteorwatch
@Hillarya_miller Just cloud cover and darkness of skies. Hope you see lots!
@Hillarya_miller Yes we are collecting a lot of data tonight with different cameras and radar. The high rate of GEMs is exciting to me!
@worldalexis @HalfSpeedHuman Yes! So some meteors you see tonight will be background meteors, not Geminids.
@amyyyylouuu yes. The brightest meteors can been seen with city lights. Would be much better if you were able to get out to darker skies!
@Marvellisaywahh You bet. We are NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office. http://t.co/EtnElnly
@LouisS Actually the green is ionized oxygen where it is burning up!
ISS has lots of armor to protect from orbital debris and meteoroids ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Freak4Nature: Gem meteoroids are sand grains to pebble-sized ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)

holamisu: Shower happens when debris burns up in Earth's atmosphere. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
kwjolley: When radiant is highest in sky -- 2 am. Hours 1-3 am should be best. ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
Geminids are ~300 times faster than the 2011 Bugatti Veyron ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
noviceggg: Look overhead, away from bright lights. GEM can be seen all over sky ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)

excited for the Geminid meteor shower tonight!! ( @nasa_marshall live at http://t.co/5HYsJ2uH)
tonight is the peak of the Geminids! One of the most impressive meteor showers of the year! Don't forget to go outside and look!
@YouriAshton Q3: I would suggest talking to a meteorologist.
@YouriAshton Q3: Hard to tell from your description - sounds like an atmospheric phenomenon to me, maybe a noctilucent cloud...
@YouriAshton Q2: nearest town.
@YouriAshton Q2: Meteors have no names. Meteorites, which are pieces that make it to the ground, are usually named after the...
@YouriAshton Q2: Most meteors come from comets, and so are fragile ice/dust mixtures, burning up high in the atmosphere
@YouriAshton Q1: Space debris entries are exceedingly rare, once-in-a-few years for a observer
@YouriAshton Q1: On a given night, you can see anywhere from 5-8 sporadic meteors per hour; naturally more during a meteor shower
@YouriAshton Q1: Meteoroids are constantly striking Earth, and those not belonging to a meteor shower are sporadic meteoroids....
@YouriAshton What was your question? If it was posted in the comments we would not see it.

Shutting down for the evening.  It's been a good night y'all!
A video recap has been reposted at http://t.co/Uowe27D
So tonight we caught a pass of ISS overhead, watched an asteroid occultation (maybe! gotta analyze the data!), & viewed Saturn & its moon
@danielbmichel1 No problem! Glad you could join us this evening!
Feel free ask me and my team questions in the chatroom at http://t.co/Uowe27D
@danielbmichel1 A gradual rise/fall in star light will be clouds
@danielbmichel1 We will analyze the data & look for a sharp drop in light from the star & also a sharp rise. That'll be occultation.
Unfortunately it's gotten too cloudy here in Huntsville, Alabama.  So we've shut down the video feed. :-(
Saturn is named after a Roman god. The Greek equivalent is Cronus.  Asteroid 52 Europa is also named for a figure in Greek mythology.
@DurkaDurkaCamel Might be hard-to-see cirrus clouds. But check with IOTA!
The moon Rhea can be seen just above the rings, on the left http://t.co/H9tmeFe
Saturn is the 2nd largest planet in the solar system.
We're now viewing Saturn on the video feed. http://t.co/H9tmeFe
@Lukasb302 An asteroid blocked out the light of a distant star for several seconds
@Asseverator Isn't modern astronomy great!
@Michael5Wright Yep!
IOTA is the International Occultation Timing Association
The IOTA website should have the results of the asteroid occultation in a few days. See http://t.co/vFMY1yh
What are the odds?!
This analysis is going to be rough.. we of course got cloud at the last second. :-(
The target star has reappeared
The target star has dimmed!!!!
30 seconds!
less than 1 minute until the occultation event! http://t.co/Uowe27D
We're about 2 minutes away from the asteroid occultation event!!!
The asteroid occultation event will begin shortly!  View it at http://t.co/Uowe27D
BUT we'll be able to see the star dim by about 2.2 mag as the asteroid travels in front of the star!
We won't be able to see the asteroid in the video feed (it's too faint!).
View the occultation at http://t.co/Uowe27D -- we'll be streaming the video! And feel free to ask me and my team questions!
52 Europa will block some of the target star's light.  This is called an occultation.
52 Europa will pass in front of star TYC 0292-00339-1 in the constellation Virgo.
52 Europa is the 7th largest asteroid (if you rank them by volume)
52 Europa is an asteroid in the asteroid belt about 280 million miles away.
We're about 15 minutes from the occultation event!  Watch the video stream and join the chat at http://t.co/Uowe27D
We are focusing on the star that will occulted by 52 Europa in about 30 minutes! Tune in to http://t.co/Uowe27D
@cmilesbaker http://t.co/Mwi1E12 You can look at Virgo in different FOV's in this link. Hope you find it!

@cmilesbaker http://t.co/lxMqFQA
There is a map of where the star is in Virgo, Saturn is on the bottom of that map.
@cmilesbaker And no, in your 300 mm lens you will not be able to get Saturn and the occulting star together in your FOV. Watch our ustream:)
@cmilesbaker Not in same FOV as Saturn, we were looking at Saturn for fun! We are now on the star though!
Another fun fact: Pluto's atmosphere was originally discovered by an occultation technique!
Occultations have discovered some fascinating things in the past! Did you know Uranus' rings were discovered by occultations? Way cool!
We are hoping for clear skies so that in about 50 minutes we can see an asteroid occultation! http://t.co/Uowe27D
We are having fun observing Saturn and answering questions while we wait for 52 Europa to occult a star! http://t.co/Uowe27D

Map showing ground track of this meteor and its orbit. Aphelion in outer part of asteroid belt nest Jupiter. http://yfrog.com/n9t3wlj
Bright sporadic over Huntsville near dawn on the 15th. Hit atmosphere at 65500 mph and ablated at 26 miles altitude. http://yfrog.com/n6qzrj

@ineedfollowers 10 pm to dawn
@KirstenJonas You can see Perseids anytime between 10 pm and dawn. The most will be seen between 3 and 4 am.
@chained nope. ISS is heavily armored and satellites are designed taking into account normal meteor activity.
